extension.searchTitle: CONCURRENT RESOLUTION ON THE BUDGET FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 160

congVote.result: So the amendment in the nature of a substitute was rejected.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Establishing the congressional budget for the United States Government for fiscal year 2018 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2019 through 2027
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to H. Con. Res. 71, establishing the congressional budget for the United States Government for fiscal year 2018 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2019 through 2027, by a yea-and-nay vote of 219 yeas to 206 nays, Roll No. 557. Consideration began yesterday, October 4th.<P/>McClintock amendment in the nature of a substitute (No. 3 printed in H. Rept. 115-339) that sought to balance the budget while bringing solvency to Social Security, Medicare, and the Federal Government, reforming the tax code, and providing for national security (by a recorded vote of 139 ayes to 281 noes, Roll No. 555); and

titleInfo.title: CONCURRENT RESOLUTION ON THE BUDGET FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018

extension.searchTitle: CONCURRENT RESOLUTION ON THE BUDGET FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 160

congVote.result: So the amendment in the nature of a substitute was rejected.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Establishing the congressional budget for the United States Government for fiscal year 2018 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2019 through 2027
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to H. Con. Res. 71, establishing the congressional budget for the United States Government for fiscal year 2018 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2019 through 2027, by a yea-and-nay vote of 219 yeas to 206 nays, Roll No. 557. Consideration began yesterday, October 4th.<P/>McClintock amendment in the nature of a substitute (No. 3 printed in H. Rept. 115-339) that sought to balance the budget while bringing solvency to Social Security, Medicare, and the Federal Government, reforming the tax code, and providing for national security (by a recorded vote of 139 ayes to 281 noes, Roll No. 555); and<P/>Yarmuth amendment in the nature of a substitute (No. 4 printed in H. Rept. 115-339) that sought to focus on fostering growth, creating jobs, and building the economy; protect health care for the middle class and struggling families and ensure national security; and support comprehensive immigration reform and disaster response funding to help Americans rebuild after the recent hurricanes (by a recorded vote of 156 ayes to 268 noes, Roll No. 556).

congVote.result: So the concurrent resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Establishing the congressional budget for the United States Government for fiscal year 2018 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2019 through 2027
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to H. Con. Res. 71, establishing the congressional budget for the United States Government for fiscal year 2018 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2019 through 2027, by a yea-and-nay vote of 219 yeas to 206 nays, Roll No. 557. Consideration began yesterday, October 4th.

CLOTURE MOTION; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 160

congVote.dailyDigestSummary: Senate confirmed the following nominations:<P/>By 65 yeas to 32 nays (Vote No. EX. 213), Randal Quarles, of Colorado, to be a Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System for the unexpired term of fourteen years from February 1, 2004.<P/>Randal Quarles, of Colorado, to be Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System for a term of four years.<P/>By 54 yeas to 43 nays (Vote No. EX. 215), Lee Francis Cissna, of Maryland, to be Director of United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, Department of Homeland Security.<P/>During consideration of this nomination today, Senate also took the following action:<P/>By 54 yeas to 43 nays (Vote No. 214), Senate agreed to the motion to close further debate on the nomination.

congVote.result: The PRESIDING OFFICER. Under the previous order, the motion to reconsider is considered made and laid upon the table and the President will be immediately notified of the Senate's action.
